tombstones, memorials, monuments, etc. schedule part description of land transferred by conveyance dated th may part description of churchyard as contained in the schedule to the act of allhallows staining church bill hl a b i l l to remove certain restrictions relating to the use of land comprising the former church of allhallows staining, its churchyard, and other adjoining land in the city of london; to make provision for the removal of any human remains from the land and to enable its use for other purposes; and for connected purposes. w hereas the livery company commonly known as the clothworkers company has owned and occupied land adjacent to the site of the former church of allhallows staining in the city of london since the th century, on which land has been built its hall provision was made by the lady slaney s estate act and an ecclesiastical scheme dated march to unite the bene ces of allhallows staining and st. olave hart street, for the removal of the church of allhallows staining , for the sale of the site of the former church, including its tower, and the adjoining curate s residence to the clothworkers company, and for the vesting of the churchyard of allhallows staining in the incumbent for the time being of the united bene ce pursuant to that act and scheme, the site of the former church, together with its tower and other adjoining land, was transferred to the clothworkers company by a conveyance dated may and that conveyance, amongst other things, obliged the clothworkers company not to pull down the tower or otherwise build on the site of the former church, and to fence in the churchyard, landscape it and keep it in good order allhallows staining church bill hl the clothworkers company s hall and the churchyard were severely damaged by bombing in and but the clothworkers company rebuilt its hall and, with the agreement of the incumbent of the united bene ce , restored, drained and paved the churchyard provision was subsequently made by the allhallows staining churchyard act for the sale of the churchyard to the clothworkers company by the incumbent of the united bene ce and for its maintenance by the clothworkers company as a private open space pursuant to the act of , the churchyard was duly conveyed to the clothworkers company by a conveyance dated june which, amongst other things, included restrictive covenants, imposed on the clothworkers company and for the bene t of the incumbent for the time being of the united bene ce, in relation to use of the churchyard which were identical to those set out in the act of it is now expedient that the site of the former church, the churchyard, the curate s residence and other adjoining land should be freed from certain restrictions in order to permit its use so far as the law otherwise allows it is expedient that the other provisions contained in this act with respect to the removal of any human remains, tombstones, memorials and monuments should be enacted it is expedient that the other provisions contained in this act should be enacted a plan dated march showing the land to which the provisions of this act apply has been deposited in the of ce of the clerk of the parliaments, house of lords, the private bill of ce of the house of commons, and the of ce of the company. the objects of this act cannot be effected without the authority of parliament may it therefore please your majesty that it may be enacted, and be it enacted, by the queen s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows citation this act may be cited as the allhallows staining church act . interpretation in this act the conveyance land means the land, comprising the site of the former church of allhallows staining including its tower and the site of the former curate s residence adjoining the church, transferred to the company by conveyance dated may in which the land was described as set out in part of the schedule to this act, and which is shown hatched and edged blue on the deposited plan; allhallows staining church bill hl the act of means the allhallows staining churchyard act ; the churchyard means the churchyard which was the subject of the act of which included the description set out in part of the schedule to this act, and which is shown hatched and edged green on the deposited plan; the company means the master, wardens and commonalty of freemen of the art or mystery of clothworkers of the city of london and its successors in title to so much of the relevant land as is in the ownership of the company; the deposited plan means the plan of the relevant land deposited as recited above; the planning acts has the same meaning as in the town and country planning act ; and the relevant land means the land edged red on the deposited plan, including the conveyance land, the churchyard, and other land hatched and edged yellow on the deposited plan comprising parts of the sites of and mark lane. repeal section to of the act of is repealed. discharge of restrictions and power to use relevant land for other purposes subject to subsections , and , and section the relevant land is freed and discharged from any restrictions in any enactment, and from all rights and interests of any person who is an heir, executor or administrator or relative of any deceased person whose remains are interred in the relevant land, and from all trusts, uses, obligations, disabilities and restrictions imposed under ecclesiastical law or otherwise which immediately before the passing of this act attached to the relevant land by reason of any part of it being consecrated land, a burial ground, a disused burial ground within the meaning of the disused burial grounds acts and , or open space; and it shall be lawful at any time to use, develop, deal with or dispose of the relevant land or any part of it for any purpose as if no part of it had ever been used or set apart for the interment of human remains. nothing in this act shall operate to affect prejudicially any private right or easement over the relevant land, or any part of it, which attached to it immediately before the coming into force of this act. the provisions of the planning acts and any restrictions or powers imposed or conferred by them in relation to land continue to apply to the relevant land. nothing in this section permits interference with land forming part of the public highway without the consent of the highway authority. allhallows staining church bill hl removal of human remains before undertaking any work to the relevant land which will involve the removal of the remains of any deceased person, the company must publish in each of two successive weeks in a newspaper circulating in the city of london; and display in a conspicuous place upon or near to the relevant land, a notice complying with subsection . notice under subsection must contain a description of the relevant land; the address at which any particulars of the deceased persons whose remains it is proposed to remove may be inspected; the name of the burial ground or crematorium where it is proposed to reinter or cremate the remains; a statement as to the right of the personal representatives or relatives of any deceased person, on notice in writing given to the company within the period mentioned in subsection , themselves to undertake the removal and reinterment or cremation of the remains of the deceased within two months from the date of the notice; a statement of any directions given by the secretary of state with respect to the removal and reinterment or cremation of human remains; and of the intentions of the company with respect to the manner of removal and the place and manner of reinterment or cremation of any human remains; and a statement that the company is required by this section to pay the reasonable expenses of such removal and reinterment or cremation. at any time within two months from the rst publication of a notice under subsection , any person who is a personal representative or relative of any deceased person whose remains are interred in the relevant land may give notice in writing to the company of that person s intention to undertake the removal of such remains, and if such remains can be identi ed, that person may then, subject to subsection cause such remains to be removed and reinterred in any burial ground or cemetery in which burials may legally take place , or to be removed to and cremated in any crematorium. immediately following any reinterment or cremation pursuant to subsection , the personal representative or relative who gave notice under that subsection in respect of it must provide to the company a certi cate for the purpose of enabling compliance with subsection . allhallows staining church bill hl if the company is not satis ed that a person giving notice under subsection is a personal representative or relative of the deceased person or that the remains in question can be identi ed, the question shall be determined, on the application of either party, by the county court, and the court shall have power to make an order specifying who shall remove the remains and as to the payment of the costs of the application. the company must pay the reasonable expenses of the removal and reinterment or cremation of remains by others under this section, subject to a limit of such sum as would be incurred by the company in the removal and reinterment or cremation of those remains. if within the said period of two months no notice under subsection has been given to the company in respect of any remains in the relevant land; or such notice is given and no application is made under subsection within two months from the giving of the notice but the person who gave the notice fails to remove the remains within a further period of two months; or within two months of any order made by the county court under subsection any person, other than the company, speci ed in the order fails to remove the remains; or it is determined that the remains to which any such notice relates cannot be identi ed, the company may remove the remains and cause them either to be reinterred in such burial ground or cemetery in which burials may legally take place as the company thinks suitable for the purpose , or cremated in such crematorium as the company thinks suitable for the purposes. if any personal representative or relative has given notice under subsection and the company or, as the case may be, the court is satis ed as to the person s status as a personal representative or relative and that the remains in question can be identi ed but that person does not remove the remains, the company must comply with any reasonable request the person may make in relation to the removal and reinterment or cremation of the remains, provided such request is received by the company within the two month period prescribed by subsection and for removing the remains. upon the reinterment or cremation of any remains under this section, the company must send a certi cate of reinterment or cremation to the registrar general giving the date of reinterment or cremation and identifying the place from which the remains were removed and the place in which they were reinterred or cremated. the removal of the remains of any deceased person under this section shall be carried out in accordance with any directions that may be given by the secretary of state. any jurisdiction or power conferred on the county court by this section may be exercised by the district judge of the court. allhallows staining church bill hl section of the burial act does not apply to a removal carried out in accordance with this section. tombstones, memorials, monuments, etc. any tombstone, memorial or monument within the relevant land may be removed to and be re erected at such other place as may be determined in accordance with this section. before any tombstone, memorial or monument is removed from any part of the relevant land the company must publish in each of two successive weeks in a newspaper circulating in the city of london; and display in a conspicuous place upon or near to the relevant land, a notice complying with subsection . notice under subsection must contain a description of the relevant land; the address at which particulars of the tombstones, memorials or monuments it is proposed to remove may be inspected; the manner in which it is proposed to deal with the tombstones, memorials or monuments; a statement as to the right of the personal representatives or relatives of any deceased person to whom a tombstone, memorial or monument relates, on notice in writing given to the company within the period mentioned in subsection , to request the re erection of the tombstone, memorial or monument; and a statement that the company is required by this section to pay the reasonable expense of removing and re erecting any tombstone, memorial or monument. if at any time within two months after the rst publication of a notice under subsection , a person who is a personal representative or relative of any deceased person to whom the tombstone, memorial or monument relates gives notice to the company requesting the re erection of the tombstone, memorial or monument, subject to subsection it is to be re erected at such other place as the parties may agree. in default of an agreement under subsection , or if the company is not satis ed that a person giving notice under subsection is a personal representative or relative of the deceased person to whom the tombstone, memorial or monument relates, the matter may be referred, by the application of either party, to the county court which may make an order specifying where the tombstone, memorial or monument must be re erected. if within the period of two months referred to in subsection no notice has been given to the company under that subsection, the tombstone, memorial or monument within the relevant land may be removed to and be re erected at such other place as the company may determine. the reasonable expense of removing and re erecting any tombstone, memorial or monument under this section must be paid by the company. allhallows staining church bill hl where any tombstone, memorial or monument is removed from the relevant land, the company must within two months from the date of removal deposit with the city of london corporation a record which identi es the tombstone, memorial or monument; gives any inscription on it; states the date and manner of its removal and disposal; and states the place to which it is transferred; and send to the registrar general a copy of the record deposited under paragraph . allhallows staining church bill hl schedule section part description of land transferred by estimation , square feet or thereabouts and having a frontage abutting on mark lane in the said city of london of feet or thereabouts together with the building now left standing thereon being the tower of the said church and also all that piece of parcel of land in the parish aforesaid and adjoining the said last mentioned piece of land and being the site of the messuage or parsonage house of the said bene ce of allhallows staining and commonly called or known as the curate s house or residence together with the said messuage or house standing thereon and also the yard and ground belonging to such messuage or house which said last mentioned piece or parcel of land yard and ground contain by estimation , square feet or thereabouts and also the passage or entrance thereto from mark lane aforesaid. part description of churchyard as contained in the schedule to the act of a piece of land in the city of london containing , square feet, or thereabouts, bounded on the north by a public footway known as star alley; on the east by land in the ownership of the company constituting part of the site of the said former church of allhallows staining and parts of the sites of former buildings known as and mark lane , upon part of which said land now stands the tower of the said former church with a crypt known as lambe s chapel crypt adjoining and upon other part of which said land now stands the parish hall of st. olave hart street ; on the south by a private courtyard known as dunster court and the exit road leading therefrom to mark lane ; and on the west by land belonging to the company upon which they have recently rebuilt their hall and erected other premises.

london local authorities and transport for london bill hl to be attached, and information on how representations can be made about the propo sal. provisions about compensation are also made in relation to damage caused by the affixing of traffic signs. similar provisions are already contained in the existing legisla tion relating to street lamps. clause makes provision about the service of notices under clause . clause makes provision about damage to highways caused as a result of the carrying out of works on land adjacent to the highway. section of the highways act provides for the recovery of expenses incurred by a highway authority incurred in remedying damage to a footway caused by or as a consequence of the carrying out of works on land adjoining it. clause would replace section with provisions for london that would enable the highway authority to recover their expenses of remedying such damage to any part of the highway, not just the footway. part builders skips part makes provision about the depositing of builders skips on the highway in lon don. the depositing of builders skips is already controlled under sections to a of the highways act . those sections provide that the permission of the highway authority is required before any builder s skip is placed on the highway. the highway authority can place conditions on the permission including conditions relating to the lighting and guarding of the skip. there are also provisions in the act requiring the owner of a builder s skip to secure that the skip is properly lighted during the hours of darkness, and that any regulations made by the secretary of state about the marking of the skip are properly complied with. responsibility for ensuring compliance with the provisions of section of the highways act lies with the owner of the builder s skip and that term is defined in section . it provides that the owner, in relation to a builder s skip which is the subject of a hiring agreement of not less than one month, or a hire purchase agreement, means the person in possession of the skip under the agreement. failure to comply with the provisions of section is a criminal offence for which the owner is liable. clause makes provision for the interpretation of terms in part . clause enables a highway authority to require the relevant person to provide them with information about who the owner of the skip is, in order to determine who penalty charge notices should be served on in respect of decriminalised contraventions of the highways act . the relevant person is defined as the person to whom permission was given under section of the highways act, or the person from whom the skip was hired, or the bailor in a hire purchase agreement. it would be an offence to fail to comply with the authority s request for information within the specified compliance period, or to give false information. clause makes provision for the decriminalisation of offences under section of the highways act as it applies in london. under part of the london local authori ties act , a regime for the administration of decriminalised offences is set out in london local authorities and transport for london bill hl some detail.clause would have the effect of applying those detailed provisions to decriminalised offences under section . clause provides that the owner of the buil der s skip would be liable to pay any penalty charge arising from a contravention of a decriminalised offence. if the skip is hired out to ano ther person, then the owner would be able to recover penalty charges from the hirer. the provisions of the act of will allow representations to be made against the imposition of penalty charge, and appeals to be made to an adjudicator. the grounds for making such representations and appeals are set out in subsection of clause . clause alters the powers of the highway authority to place conditions on the giving of a permission for placing a skip on the highway. it will enable the authority to include a condition that the skip has lights or a guard or system of guarding that is an integral part of the skip. clause provides highway authorities with powers to light and cover skips in cases where requirements as to lighting and covering have not been complied with. the clause enables the highway authority to recover any expenses reasonably incurred in lighting or covering the skip. clause would enable a highway authority to fix an immobilisation device to a skip in cases where they have also served a penalty charge notice . the clause also makes requirements of the authority to affix a notice to the skip providing informa tion about how to secure its removal and there are offences for unlawfully removing the skip or the notice. clause sets out the circumstances under which a skip will be released from an immo bilisation device. it will be removed when the penalty charge and a release fee are paid. clause makes additional provision about appeals against penalty charges in cases where a skip has been immobilised under clause . it provides that where representa tions or an appeal have been made successfully, the highway authority must refund any charges made for the release of the skip as well as the penalty charge for the contra vention. part road traffic part contains a single provision relating to road traffic. clause deals with cases where the local traffic authority has made a road traffic regu lation order under the road traffic regulation act so as to prevent the passage of vehicles or any class of vehicles into out of or along a highway, and has also placed a gate or other barrier on the highway to ensure that the order is complied with. someti mes the barriers are authorised to be opened, for example, by the emergency services. whilst it is an offence to drive along the road in breach of the road traffic regulation order, it is not an offence to interfere with the barrier unless criminal damage is caused. clause makes it an offence to open, close or otherwise interfere with a barrier without lawful excuse. london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part charging points for electric reasonablecharges.therearealsoprovisionsaboutliabilityinrespectofinjury,damageor loss arising from the presence of charging apparatus on the highway. clause sets out a procedure for giving notice clause . there are also special provisions relating to highways maintained by railway undertakers. clause makes provision about the unlawful use of charging points provided under part . it provides offence to so use the apparatus. defences are set out in subsection . part london local authorities and transport for london act part consistsofoneclause,namelyclause this act may be cited as the london local authorities and transport for london act . this act, except the provisions mentioned in subsection shall come into operation at the end of the period of two months beginning with the date on which it is passed. the following provisions shall come into operation on the appointed day sections and ; part . interpretation in this act the act means the highways act ; borough council means london borough council and includes the common council of the city of london in its capacity as a local authority; joint committee means, except in section , any joint committee established under section of the local government act and comprising at least one member from each borough council and at least one person appointed by transport for london; london authority means a borough council or transport for london, as the case may be; relevant highway authority means a borough council, as respects highways for which they are the highway authority; transport for london, as respects highways for which they are the highway authority. appointed day in section the appointed day means such day as may be fixed as regards the provisions mentioned in that section by a decision of transport for london; or london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part preliminary by resolution of a borough council, as the case may be, subject to and in accordance with the provisions of this section. different days may be fixed under this section for the purpose of the application of the provisions mentioned in section to different areas. different days may be fixed under this section for the purpose of the application of the provisions mentioned in section to an area. the london authority in question shall cause to be published in a local newspaper circulating in their area and in the london gazette, notice of the passing of any such resolution or taking of any such decision under this section and of the day fixed by the resolution or decision; and of the general effect of the provisions coming into operation on that day, and the day so fixed shall not be earlier than the expiration of one month from the publication of the notice in the london gazette. a document certified by the officer appointed for that purpose by the london authority in question to be a true reproduction of a page or part of a page of any subsection . under the said section or the said section as modified by this section a london authority shall not affix anything to a building that does not form part of the operational land of a statutory undertaker unless they have complied with the requirements of subsections to . not less than days before the london authority propose to begin the work to affix an attachment or a traffic sign to a building they shall serve notice in writing on the relevant owner of the building of their proposal to affix it. the notice shall state that the authority propose to affix an attachment or a traffic sign to the building; describe the attachment or traffic sign, giving its approximate dimensions; specify where on the building the authority propose to affix it and the means by which it is to be fixed; specify the date, or the earliest date, on which the authority propose to begin the work; specify a period of not less than days from the date of service of the notice during which the relevant owner may make representations to the authority about the proposal; inform the relevant owner of his rights to compensation for damage which might be suffered by or in consequence of the affixing of the attachment or traffic sign; inform the relevant owner that if no representations are made within the period specified in the notice for doing so the authority may proceed with their proposal without further notice. if a notice specifies an earliest date under subsection , the authority may not begin the work after the expiry of four months beginning with that date . the london authority shall, having considered any representations made by the relevant owner within the period specified in the notice served under subsection , decide to proceed with their proposal; to proceed with their proposal modified to take account of any representations made; not to proceed with their proposal. if the relevant owner has made representations the london authority shall serve notice on him of its decision. under the said section or the said section as modified by this section a london authority shall not affix anything to a building that forms part of the operational land of a statutory undertaker without the written consent of the statutory undertaker in question. consent may be given subject to reasonable conditions and shall not be unreasonably withheld. london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part highways miscellaneous where a london authority serves on a statutory undertaker a notice requesting that undertaker s consent under subsection to the affixing of anything to a building; and the statutory undertaker does not within the period of days beginning with the date upon which the notice is served give their consent unconditionally or give it subject to conditions or refuse it, the consent shall be deemed to have been withheld. where, in the opinion of a london authority, a consent required under subsection for the affixing of anything to a building is unreasonably withheld or given subject to unreasonable conditions, the london authority may apply to the magistrates court, who may either allow the thing in question to be affixed subject to such conditions, if any, as it thinks fit; or disallow the application. a london authority may not, under section , appoint a day for the purposes of this section until a code of practice dealing with the exercise of the powers of the said section and the said section as modified by this section has been published by a joint committee. this section and section shall not apply in respect of a theatre. in this section attachment has the same meaning as in section of the public health act ; building includes any structure and a bridge or aqueduct; joint committee means any joint committee established under section of the local government act and comprising at least one person appointed by transport for london; and one member of each borough council other than the common council ; operational land has the same meaning as in the town and country planning act ; relevant owner in relation to a building occupied by a person under a lease or tenancy having an unexpired term of five years or more, means that person; or in relation to any other building, means the person for the time being receiving the rack rent of the building whether on his own account or as agent or trustee for any other person, or who would so receive it if the building were let at a rack rent; statutory undertaker has the same meaning as in section of the town and country planning act ; theatre means any building or part of a building used wholly or mainly for the public performance of plays and public performance and play have the same meanings as in the theatres act , but with the words dance performance substituted for ballet ; london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part highways miscellaneous traffic sign has the same meaning as in section of the road traffic regulation act . service of notices under section a notice under section , or may be served by post. where the person on whom a notice to be served is a body corporate, the notice or document is duly served if it is served on the secretary or clerk of that body. for the purposes of section of the interpretation act as it applies for the purposes of this section, the proper address of any person in relation to the service on him of a notice under subsection is, if he has given an address for service, that address, and otherwise in the case of the secretary or clerk of a body corporate, the registered or principal office of that body; and in any other case, his last known address at the time of service. if, for the purposes of serving a notice under section the name or address of the relevant owner cannot be ascertained after reasonable enquiry, the notice may be served by addressing it to him by name or by the description of owner of the land ; and either leaving it in the hands of a person who is or appears to be resident or employed on the land or leaving it conspicuously affixed to some building or object on or near the land. this section shall not be taken to exclude the employment of any method of service not expressly provided for by it. damage to highways in consequence of adjacent works the act shall apply in greater london as though for section and its heading there were substituted damage to highway by carrying out of works if a highway maintainable at the public expense is damaged by or in consequence of any works on land adjacent to the highway, the highway authority for the highway may make good the damage and recover the expenses reasonably incurred by them in doing so from the owner of the land in question; or the person carrying out the works; or the person on whose behalf the works were carried out. . london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part builders skips part builders skips interpretation of part in this part the act means the london local authorities act ; builder s skip has the same meaning as in section of the act; immobilisation device means any device or appliance designed or adapted to be fixed to a builder s skip for the purpose of preventing it from being moved; owner in relation to a builder s skip, is to be construed in accordance with section of the act. identifying the owner of a builder s skip a relevant highway authority may, for the purposes of identifying who is responsible for paying a penalty charge for the purposes of section of the act as applied by virtue of section , require the relevant person to provide them with the name and address of the owner of the builder s skip. in subsection , the relevant person is if a permission was given to a person in respect of the skip in question under section of the act and the penalty charge became payable during the period of the permission, that person; if different from the person mentioned in paragraph , the person who the relevant highway authority have reason to believe in the case of a builder s skip that is the subject of a hiring agreement for a hire of not less than one month, the person from whom the skip was hired; and in the case of a builder s skip that is the subject of a hire purchase agreement, the bailor under that agreement. the person identified by the relevant person shall be an individual, a body corporate, an unincorporated association or other body that is capable of being sued. a requirement under this section shall specify the period within which it must be complied with, which must be a period no shorter than working days beginning with the date on which the request was made. a person on whom a requirement is imposed under this section commits an offence if without reasonable excuse he fails to comply within the period specified in accordance with subsection ; in responding to the requirement he gives information that he knows is false in a material particular. a person convicted of an offence under subsection is liable on summary conviction london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part builders skips in the case of an offence under paragraph to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale; in the case of an offence under paragraph to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale. builders skips penalty charge provisions this section is a penalty charge provision for the purposes of section of the act . part of the act shall have effect so far as that part applies by virtue of this section being designated as a penalty charge provision as mentioned in subsection as if for references to a borough council there were substituted references to a relevant highway authority within the meaning of this act. a penalty charge is payable to a relevant highway authority for the purposes of the said section if a builder s skip is deposited on a highway without a permission granted under section of the act ; a builder s skip has been deposited on a highway in accordance with a permission granted under the said section but the owner of the skip does not secure that the skip is properly lighted during the hours of darkness; the skip is marked or lighted in accordance with regulations made under the said section requiring builders skips to be so marked or lighted; the skip is clearly and indelibly marked with the owner s name and with his telephone number or address; the skip is removed as soon as practicable after it has been filled; each of the conditions subject to which the permission was granted is complied with; the owner of a builder s skip who, under subsection of section of the act , is required to remove or reposition the skip or cause it to be removed or repositioned has failed to comply with the requirement as soon as is practicable. for the purposes of the said section of the act as it applies in respect of penalty charges payable under that section by virtue of subsection , a penalty charge is payable to a relevant highway authority by the owner of the builder s skip in respect of which the contravention of the relevant provision in question is alleged to have occurred. the owner of the builder s skip is the appropriate recipient for the purposes of the said section . for the purposes of section of the act the grounds on which representations may be made against a penalty charge notice arising from a penalty charge payable by virtue of this section are that the recipient never was the owner of the builder s skip in question; had ceased to be the owner before the date on which the penalty charge was alleged to have become payable; london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part builders skips became the owner after that date; that there was no contravention of the relevant provision in question and in respect of which the penalty charge notice was issued; that the penalty charge exceeded the amount applicable in the circumstances of the case; that the contravention of the relevant provision in question was due to the act or default of another person and that he took all precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the contravention by himself or another person under his control. where any of the grounds mentioned in subsection is relied on in any representations made under the said section , those representations must include a statement of the name and address of the owner . where the ground mentioned in subsection is relied on in any representations made under the said section , the relevant highway authority may disregard the representations unless, before the representations are considered, the person making the representations has served on the relevant highway authority a notice in writing giving such information identifying or assisting in the identification of that other person as was then in his possession. subsections to of section and subsection of section of the act cease to have effect in greater london. section of the act in its application to greater london, is amended by the substitution for guilty of an offence under section above of failing of the words liable to pay a penalty charge under section of the london local authorities and transport for london act in relation to the failure . the entries numbered to in the table contained in schedule to the london local authorities and transport for london act are repealed. builders skips requirements as to lighting and guarding conditions of the type referred to in section of the act to which a permission under section of the act may be made subject, may include conditions that builders skips have a light or lights or a guard or system of guarding that is or are an integral part of the skip. builders skips provision of lighting and covering by highway authority subsection applies if a builder s skip is found by a relevant highway authority to be deposited on a highway in greater london and the skip is not lighted or covered in accordance with the conditions of a permission under section of the act; was deposited without a permission under that section having been obtained; or is not properly lighted during the hours of darkness of the act . london local authorities and transport for london bill hl part builders skips where this section applies, the relevant highway authority in question may themselves light, cover or mark the skip or cause it to be lighted, covered or marked. any expenses reasonably incurred by a relevant highway authority in the lighting, covering or marking of a skip under subsection may be recovered from the owner of the skip in any court of competent jurisdiction or summarily as a civil debt. the owner of a skip is not liable to pay a penalty charge under section in relation to a failure to secure that a condition or requirement relating to the lighting, covering or marking of the skip was complied with if the failure resulted from the lighting, covering or marking of the skip under subsection . builders skips immobilisation devices where a penalty charge notice has been served in accordance with section of the act in relation to a penalty charge payable under section , an authorised officer of the relevant highway authority or a person acting under his direction may fix an immobilisation device to the builder s skip concerned while it remains in the place where it was found. on any occasion when an immobilisation device is fixed to a skip in accordance with this section, the person fixing the device shall also fix to the skip a notice indicating that such a device has been fixed to the skip and warning that no attempt should be made to move it until it has been released from that device; specifying the steps to be taken in order to secure its release; and warning that unlawful removal of an immobilisation device is an offence. a notice fixed to a skip in accordance with this section shall not be removed or interfered with except by or under the authority of the owner of the skip; or the relevant highway authority. a person contravening subsection shall be guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale. any person who, without being authorised to do so in accordance with this section, removes or attempts to remove an immobilisation device fixed to a skip in accordance with this section shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale. release of immobilised skips a skip to which an immobilisation device has been fixed in accordance with section may only be released from that device by or under the direction of a person authorised by the relevant highway authority to give such a direction. subject to subsection , such a skip shall be released from the device on payment in any manner specified in the notice fixed to the skip under section of london local authorities and extracted_text: bill european union bill hl contents approval of draft decisions under article of tfeu extent, commencement and short title bill european union bill hl a b i l l to make provision approving for the purposes of section of the european union act certain draft decisions under article of the treaty on the functioning of the european union. e it enacted by the queen s most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows approval of draft decisions under article of tfeu this section has effect for the purposes of section of the european union act . the following draft decisions of the council of the european union under article of tfeu are approved the draft decision on the participation of the former yugoslav republic of macedonia as an observer in the work of the european union agency for fundamental rights , and the draft decision on a tripartite social summit for growth and employment . in this section tfeu means the treaty on the functioning of the european union. extent, commencement and short title this act extends to the whole of the united kingdom. this act comes into force on the day on which it is passed. this act may be cited as the european union act . b

meaning of charity and charitable purpose chapter general charity meaning of charity for the purposes of the law of england and wales, charity means an institution which is established for charitable purposes only, and falls to be subject to the control of the high court in the exercise of its jurisdiction with respect to charities. the definition of charity in subsection does not apply for the purposes of an enactment if a different definition of that term applies for those purposes by virtue of that or any other enactment. charitable purpose meaning of charitable purpose for the purposes of the law of england and wales, a charitable purpose is a purpose which b charities bill hl part meaning of charity and charitable purpose chapter general falls within section , and is for the public benefit . any reference in any enactment or document to charitable purposes, or to institutions having purposes that are charitable under the law relating to charities in england and wales, is to be read in accordance with subsection . subsection does not apply where the context otherwise requires. this section is subject to section . descriptions of purposes a purpose falls within this subsection if it falls within any of the following descriptions of purposes the prevention or relief of poverty; the advancement of education; the advancement of religion; the advancement of health or the saving of lives; the advancement of citizenship or community development; the advancement of the arts, culture, heritage or science; the advancement of amateur sport; the advancement of human rights, conflict resolution or reconciliation or the promotion of religious or racial harmony or equality and diversity; the advancement of environmental protection or improvement; the relief of those in need because of youth, age, ill health, disability, financial hardship or other disadvantage; the advancement of animal welfare; the promotion of the efficiency of the armed forces of the crown or of the efficiency of the police, fire and rescue services or ambulance services; any other purposes that are not within paragraphs to but are recognised as charitable purposes by virtue of section or under the old law, that may reasonably be regarded as analogous to, or within the spirit of, any purposes falling within any of paragraphs to or sub paragraph , or that may reasonably be regarded as analogous to, or within the spirit of, any purposes which have been recognised, under the law relating to charities in england and wales, as falling within sub paragraph or this sub paragraph. in subsection in paragraph , religion includes a religion which involves belief in more than one god, and a religion which does not involve belief in a god, charities bill hl part meaning of charity and charitable purpose chapter general in paragraph , the advancement of health includes the prevention or relief of sickness, disease or human suffering, paragraph includes rural or urban regeneration, and the promotion of civic responsibility, volunteering, the voluntary sector or the effectiveness or efficiency of charities, in paragraph , sport means sports or games which promote health by involving physical or mental skill or exertion, paragraph includes relief given by the provision of accommodation or care to the persons mentioned in that paragraph, and in paragraph , fire and rescue services means services provided by fire and rescue authorities under part of the fire and rescue services act . where any of the terms used in any of paragraphs to of subsection , or in subsection , has a particular meaning under the law relating to charities in england and wales, the term is to be taken as having the same meaning where it appears in that provision. in subsection , the old law means the law relating to charities in england and wales as in force immediately before april . the public benefit requirement in this act the public benefit requirement means the requirement in section that a purpose falling within section must be for the public benefit if it is to be a charitable purpose. in determining whether the public benefit requirement is satisfied in relation to any purpose falling within section , it is not to be presumed that a purpose of a particular description is for the public benefit. in this chapter any reference to the public benefit is a reference to the public benefit as that term is understood for the purposes of the law relating to charities in england and wales. subsection is subject to subsection . recreational trusts and registered sports clubs recreational and similar trusts, etc. it is charitable to provide, or assist in the provision of, facilities for recreation, or other leisure time occupation, if the facilities are provided in the interests of social welfare. the requirement that the facilities are provided in the interests of social welfare cannot be satisfied if the basic conditions are not met. the basic conditions are that the facilities are provided with the object of improving the conditions of life for the persons for whom the facilities are primarily intended, and charities bill hl part meaning of charity and charitable purpose chapter general that those persons have need of the facilities because of their youth, age, infirmity or disability, poverty, or social and economic circumstances, or the facilities are to be available to members of the public at large or to male, or to female, members of the public at large. subsection applies in particular to the provision of facilities at village halls, community centres and women s institutes, and the provision and maintenance of grounds and buildings to be used for purposes of recreation or leisure time occupation, and extends to the provision of facilities for those purposes by the organising of any activity. but this is subject to the requirement that the facilities are provided in the interests of social welfare. nothing in this section is to be treated as derogating from the public benefit requirement. registered sports clubs a registered sports club established for charitable purposes is to be treated as not being so established, and accordingly cannot be a charity. in subsection , registered sports club means a registered club within the meaning of chapter of part of the corporation tax act . supplementary application of this chapter in relation to scotland this chapter affects the law of scotland only in so far as it affects the construction of references to charities, or charitable purposes, in enactments which relate to matters falling within section a of part of schedule to the scotland act . in so far as this chapter affects the law of scotland references in sections and to the law of england and wales are to be read as references to the law of scotland, and the reference in section to the high court is to be read as a reference to the court of session. application of this chapter in relation to northern charitable purpose chapter general in enactments which relate to matters falling within paragraph of schedule to the northern ireland act . in so far as this chapter affects the law of northern ireland references in sections and to the law of england and wales are to be read as references to the law of northern ireland, and the reference in section to the high court is to be read as a act institution means an institution whether incorporated or not, and includes a trust or undertaking. subsections to apply except where the context otherwise requires. chapter special provision for but in the rest of this act charity is not applicable to any ecclesiastical corporation in respect of the corporate property of the corporation, except a corporation aggregate having some purposes the diocese, or any trust of property for purposes for which the property has been consecrated. ecclesiastical corporation means any corporation in the church of england, whether sole or aggregate, established for any special purposes of or in connection with a charity is to be treated as forming part of that charity, or as forming a distinct charity. the commission may direct that for all or any of the purposes of this act two or more charities having the same charity trustees are to be treated as a single charity. part the charity commission and the official custodian for charities the commission the charity commission there continues to be a body corporate known as the charity commission for england and wales . in welsh the commission is known as comisiwn elusennau cymru a lloegr . the functions of the commission are performed on behalf of the crown. in the exercise of its functions the commission is not subject to the direction or control of any minister of the crown or of another government department. but subsection does not affect any provision made by or under any enactment; any administrative controls exercised over the commission s expenditure by the treasury. schedule contains provisions relating to the commission. the commission s objectives the commission has the following objectives . the public confidence objective the public confidence objective is to increase public trust and confidence in charities. . the public benefit objective the public benefit objective is to promote awareness and understanding of the operation of the public benefit requirement. charities bill hl part the charity commission and the official custodian for charities the commission s general functions the commission has the following general functions the commission may, in connection with its second general function, give such advice or guidance with respect to the administration of charities as it considers appropriate. any advice or guidance so given may relate to charities generally, any class of charities, or any particular charity, and may take such form, and be given in such manner, as the commission considers appropriate. the commiss

london local authorities bill hl clause makes provision about street litter control notices. street litter control notices are notices served under section of the environmental protection act . they can be served by the principal litter authority imposing requirements on occupiers of premises with a view to the prevention of accumulations of litter or refuse in and around any street or open land adjacent to any street. under section of the act, the secretary of state is given power to prescribe the descriptions of commercial or retail premises in respect of which a street litter control notice may be issued, amongst other things. the effect of clause would be to extend the type of premises which the secretary of state can prescribe under section so that it includes all premises in greater london except for dwellings. this will bring into the scope of the street litter control notice procedures public buildings and other buildings which are not commercial or retail premises. the amount of litter generated by smokers who are no longer able to smoke inside places of work is one of the reasons for this proposed alteration in the legislation in london. clause amends the application of the public lavatories act in greater london. section of that act provides that every turnstile in any part of a public lavatory or public sanitary convenience controlled or managed by a local authority or in any entrance or exit of such lavatory or convenience had to be removed six months after the act obtained royal assent. it also provided that no turnstile should be provided in the future. clause disapplies those provisions in greater london. clause alters provisions in the highways act which enable local authorities to give permissions for the use of objects, etc. on the highway. part viia of the act was inserted by the local government miscellaneous provisions act and it enables the councils themselves to place objects or structures on, in or over a highway and also give permission to others to do so. section e of the act is the provision which enables the councils to give such permissions to others and section f enables the councils to place conditions on any permission given under section e. it provides that the councils can require the payment of such reasonable charges as they may determine. subsection of section f provides that except where the council are the owners of the sub soil beneath the part of the highway in relation to which the permission is granted, the charges may not exceed the standard amount and the standard amount is defined in subsection of section f. in turn that provides that in relation to permissions given to others to place objects on the highway, the charges that the council may make must not exceed their reasonable expenses in connection with granting the permission . clause would allow london borough councils to take into account additional considerations when setting the level of charges in relation to cases where they have given their permission under section e, namely where they have given permission for the placing of objects on the highway where doing so will result in the production of income. a typical example of when this might happen is where the council has given permission for a restaurant to place tables and chairs on the highway. clause would enable the council, when setting the charges, to include in their calculations reasonable costs in the aggregate incurred in relation to the reasonable administrative or other costs incurred in granting permissions, additional street cleansing costs arising from activities for which permission is granted, and additional enforcement costs. london local authorities bill hl part licensing part deals with various miscellaneous licensing regimes applicable in greater london. clause amends the city of westminster act which provides westminster city council with enhanced enforcement powers in relation to unlicensed sex establishments. the first amendment is a minor typographical amendment and the second amends section of the act, which relates to the service of notices. under section , if notices under the act are to be served by post, then they have to be served by registered post or the recorded delivery service. the amendments would enable notices to be served by ordinary post. clause makes further provision about street trading, in relation to the sale of vehicles over the internet. under the existing street trading legislation in london, street trading is defined, broadly speaking, as meaning the selling or the exposure or offer for sale of any article and the supplying of or offering to supply any service in a street for gain or reward . under that definition it is unclear whether the sale of motor vehicles on the internet, where the vehicle is kept on the highway, is included and the effect of clause will be to ensure that it is. clauses to deal with street trading in the city of westminster. westminster city council have their own private legislation, namely the city of westminster act which deals with street trading in the city. it should be noted that since the deposit of this bill, the council have deposited a further private bill which if enacted would repeal the act and re enact it with amendments, including amendments equivalent to those described in the following paragraphs. clause contains a number of amendments to the act. the first amendments of substance are in subsections to and they replicate in westminster the effect of the amendments which are made by clause in respect of the rest of london . taken together, subsections to introduce a series of amendments which will enable authorised officers of the city council to seize certain types of street trading equipment in cases where they couldn t do so under the present legislation, and to dispose of it summarily in certain cases. westminster city council officers already have power to seize items used in unlawful street trading where the items are required for evidential purposes, or where the items are subject to forfeiture by the courts. on a street trading prosecution, if there is a conviction, the magistrates court can order the forfeiture of any goods seized in relation to the offence. authorised officers cannot exercise their powers of seizure unless they suspect that a street trading offence has been committed. city council officers use the powers regularly in the west end in relation to unlawful sales of hotdogs and other hot food from portable stands. each evening portable stands are london local authorities bill hl brought into the west end by van and are unloaded together before being taken off by individual sellers to strategic locations, where the trading takes place. city council officers are unable to seize the hotdog trolleys until the vending begins. additional powers are contained in subsection of clause . they would enable city council officers to seize receptacles which are in a street and which the officers have reasonable cause to suspect are intended to be used in connection with a street trading offence. officers would also be able to seize any vehicle used to transport the receptacles to the place where they were found in the street. subsections onwards introduce a new procedure for dealing with receptacles used in unlawful street trading of refreshments when they have been seized. this would include receptacles seized under the new powers mentioned above introduced by subsection . under the current system, where the council seize items under section of the act, they either have to return them to the person from whom they were seized, if certain circumstances arise, or they can be disposed of if there is a conviction and the court orders the items to be forfeited. the council can also apply to the magistrates court for a disposal order if the court is satisfied that the council has made reasonable efforts to ascertain the identity of the owner of the objects seized but failed. westminster city council seize very large numbers of hot dog trolleys in the west end and because of the procedures that they have to go through, they have to store the trolleys for long periods at considerable expense. in nearly all cases, the trolleys are eventually disposed of by the council because either the person from whom the trolley was seized does not contest the criminal proceedings, or the council is unable to find out who the owner of the trolley is. the effect of subsections to will be to enable the council to dispose of hot dog trolleys and other receptacles for the sale of refreshments without the need to go to court either to secure a prosecution or obtain a disposal order. safeguards are included in the clauses to ensure that if the person from whom the receptacle is seized wishes there to be a court hearing, then he can secure it. this is achieved by including a requirement on the officer who seizes the item to give the person from whom it was seized a notice. the notice can be completed by the recipient and returned to the council, and if it is done so within the time stated on the notice and contains all the necessary information and states that the recipient requires the council to seek a disposal order from the magistrates court, then the council would be under an obligation to seek such an order. at the magistrates court hearing, the recipient of the notice would have the opportunity to contest the proceedings. if the notice is not completed and returned to the council in the correct manner and within the specified time, then the council will be able to dispose of the item in question and cover their costs of doing so from the recipient, if they are able to identify and find him. the powers of summary disposal would also be available to the council if when seizing the item they served a fixed penalty notice on the person from whom the item was seized. if the fixed penalty is paid within the required timescale, then the council would be able to dispose of the item. clause introduces schedule which in turn makes minor and consequential amendments to the city of westminster act , consequential upon the amendments made in clause . london local authorities bill hl clause introduces schedule to the bill which is a keeling schedule setting out the whole of the city of westminster act as amended by previous enactments and by the bill. clauses to make similar provision in the london borough of camden as clause does in westminster in relation to the seizure and disposal of receptacles used for the purposes of unlawful street trading of refreshments. clause provides for interpretation of the camden provisions and clause makes similar provision to clause about the seizure of receptacles before street trading commences. clauses and make similar provision to clause to about the giving of notices and the disposal of seized items. part miscellaneous and supplemental part contains miscellaneous and supplemental provisions. clause contains provisions correcting two small errors in the london local authorities act . the first alteration is in respect of section . that subsection makes an amendment to section of the environmental protection act . the subsection did not take account of amendments recently made to section by the clean neighbourhoods and environment act . subsection corrects a reference in section . the reference to waste regulation authority is corrected so that it reads waste collection authority . clause provides for an offence of obstructing an authorised officer acting in the exercise of his powers under the bill, and a maximum punishment for such an offence is a fine not exceeding level on the standard scale, on summary conviction. clause makes provision about the requirements for proof, in court proceedings, of the fact that a borough council has passed a resolution under the bill. the clause provides that it shall be presumed, unless the contrary is proved, that the resolution was duly passed and that any requirements relating to it were properly complied with. clause makes provision about the liability of directors and other officers of bodies corporate in relation to offences committed under the bill. european convention on human rights in the view of the westminster city council the provisions of the london local authorities bill are compatible with the convention rights. hc london local authorities bill hl as amended in committee contents part preliminary citation and commencement general interpretation part penalty charges powers exercisable by police civilians and accredited persons power to require name and address part public health, environmental protection and highways street litter control notices use of turnstiles at public toilets charges for permitting the use of objects, etc. on the highway part licensing miscellaneous amendment of city of westminster act street trading vehicles and the internet london local authorities bill hl ii city of westminster act street trading in the city of westminster minor and consequential amendments keeling schedule street trading in the london borough of camden interpretation of camden provisions seizure of certain objects seizure notices return and disposal of seized objects by council part miscellaneous and supplemental minor amendments to london local authorities act , etc. obstruction of authorised officer proof of resolution liability of directors, etc. schedule minor and consequential amendments to city of westminster act schedule city of westminster act as having effect as amended by section of the london local authorities act , chapter of part of the london local authorities act and this act london local authorities bill hl a b i l l as amended in committee to confer further powers upon local authorities in london; and for related purposes. whereas it is expedient that further and better provision should be made for the improvement and development of local government services in london and for the benefit of persons residing therein and that the powers of london borough councils and the common council of the city of london should be extended and amended as provided in this act it is expedient that further provision be made in london about the use of penalty charges in the enforcement of certain legislation it is expedient that the range of premises in london in respect of which street litter control notices can be served should be extended it is expedient that london borough councils should be able to install turnstiles in public conveniences it is expedient that london borough councils should be able to make increased charges when giving permissions for the execution of works and use of objects on the highway, if the execution of works and use of objects produces income it is expedient that the law relating to street trading in london should be altered to clarify that internet sales of vehicles that are kept on the street fall within its scope london local authorities bill hl it is expedient that the law relating to street trading in the city of westminster and the london borough of camden should be altered in relation to the seizure and disposal of receptacles used or about to be used for unlawful street trading it is expedient that the other provisions contained in this act should be enacted the objects of this act cannot be attained without the authority of parliament in relation to the promotion of the bill for this act the westminster city council have complied with the requirements of section of the local government act and the other participating london borough councils have complied with the requirements of section
